1.brief: to flit, i.e. vanish away (subside, escape; causatively, chase, impel, deliver)
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
to run after (usually with hostile intent; figuratively (of time) gone by)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
a village (as covered in by walls); also a young lion (perhaps as covered with a mane)
figuratively, to trust, be confident or sure

2.brief: the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
a head person (of any rank or class)
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
to separate mentally (or distinguish), i.e.(generally) understand

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
properly, set upright; hence (figuratively as adjective) just; but usually (as adverb or conjunction) rightly or so (in various applications to manner, time and relation; often with other particles)
to be (causative, make) long (literally or figuratively)

3.brief: properly, a valiant man or warrior; generally, a person simply
to press upon, i.e. oppress, defraud, violate, overflow
properly, dangling, i.e. (by implication) weak or thin
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
food (for man or beast), especially bread, or grain (for making it)

4.brief: to loosen, i.e. relinquish, permit, etc.
a precept or statute, especially the Decalogue or Pentateuch
to be clear (orig. of sound, but usually of color); to shine; hence, to make ashow, to boast; and thus to be (clamorously) foolish; to rave; causatively, to celebrate; also to stultify
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
a precept or statute, especially the Decalogue or Pentateuch
properly, to grate, i.e. (figuratively) to anger

5.brief: a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to separate mentally (or distinguish), i.e.(generally) understand

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style
to search out (by any method, specifically in worship or prayer); by implication, to strive after
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
to separate mentally (or distinguish), i.e.(generally) understand
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)

6.brief: good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
to walk (in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are

7.brief: to guard, in a good sense (to protect, maintain, obey, etc.) or a bad one (to conceal, etc.)
a precept or statute, especially the Decalogue or Pentateuch
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
to separate mentally (or distinguish), i.e.(generally) understand
to tend a flock; i.e. pasture it; intransitively, to graze (literally or figuratively); generally to rule; by extension, to associate with (as a friend)
to shake (as in the wind), i.e. to quake; figuratively, to be loose morally, worthless or prodigal
properly, to wound; but only figuratively, to taunt or insult
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application

8.brief: multiplication, i.e. percentage or bonus in addition to principal
properly, to bend or stoop in kindness to an inferior; to favor, bestow; causatively to implore (i.e. move to favor by petition)
properly, dangling, i.e. (by implication) weak or thin

9.brief: broadness. i.e. (concrete) the ear (from its form in man)
to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
a precept or statute, especially the Decalogue or Pentateuch
properly, assemblage; used only adverbially also, even, yea, though; often repeated as correl. both...and
intercession, supplication; by implication, a hymn
properly, something disgusting (morally), i.e. (as noun) an abhorrence; especially idolatry or (concretely) an idol

10.brief: to stray (causatively, mislead), usually (figuratively) to mistake, especially (morally) to transgress; by extension (through the idea of intoxication) to reel, (figuratively) be enraptured
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)
entire (literally, figuratively or morally); also (as noun) integrity, truth
to inherit (as a (figurative) mode of descent), or (generally) to occupy; causatively, to bequeath, or (generally) distribute, instate

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)

11.brief: an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
properly, dangling, i.e. (by implication) weak or thin
to separate mentally (or distinguish), i.e.(generally) understand
properly, to penetrate; hence, to examine intimately

12.brief: to jump for joy, i.e. exult
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
ornament (abstractly or concretely, literally or figuratively)
to rise (in various applications, literal, figurative, intensive and causative)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to seek; causatively, to conceal oneself (i.e. let be sought), or mask
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)

13.brief: properly, to plump, i.e. fill up hollows; by implication, to cover (for clothing or secrecy)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to push forward, in various senses (literal or figurative, transitive or intransitive)
physically, to throw (a stone, an arrow) at or away; especially to revere or worship (with extended hands); intensively, to bemoan (by wringing the hands)
to loosen, i.e. relinquish, permit, etc.
to fondle; by implication, to love, especially to compassionate

14.brief: happiness; only in masculine plural construction as interjection, how happy!
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
to be startled (by a sudden alarm); hence, to fear in general
properly, continuance (as indefinite extension); but used only (attributively as adjective) constant (or adverbially, constantly); ellipt. the regular (daily) sacrifice
properly, to be dense, i.e. tough or severe (in various applications)
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)

15.brief: to course (like a beast of prey); by implication, to seek greedily
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
properly, dangling, i.e. (by implication) weak or thin

16.brief: a commander (as occupying the front), civil, military or religious; generally (abstractly, plural), honorable themes
intelligence; by implication, an argument; by extension, caprice
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
to be (causative, make) long (literally or figuratively)
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)

17.brief: ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
to press upon, i.e. oppress, defraud, violate, overflow
blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
a pit hole (especially one used as a cistern or a prison)
to flit, i.e. vanish away (subside, escape; causatively, chase, impel, deliver)
not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
to sustain; by implication, to obtain, keep fast; figuratively, to help, follow close

18.brief: to walk (in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively)
entire (literally, figuratively or morally); also (as noun) integrity, truth
properly, to be open, wide or free, i.e. (by implication) to be safe; causatively, to free or succor
to knot or distort; figuratively, to pervert (act or declare perverse)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)
properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first

19.brief: to work (in any sense); by implication, to serve, till, (causatively) enslave, etc.
to sate, i.e. fill to satisfaction (literally or figuratively)
food (for man or beast), especially bread, or grain (for making it)
to run after (usually with hostile intent; figuratively (of time) gone by)
to sate, i.e. fill to satisfaction (literally or figuratively)

20.brief: a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
literally firmness; figuratively security; morally fidelity
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
to press; (by implication) to be close, hurry, withdraw
properly, to accumulate; chiefly (specifically) to grow (causatively, make) rich
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to be (or make) clean (literally or figuratively); by implication (in an adverse sense) to be bare, i.e. extirpated

21.brief: properly, to scrutinize, i.e. look intently at; hence (with recognition implied), to acknowledge, be acquainted with, care for, respect, revere, or (with suspicion implied), to disregard, ignore, be strange toward, reject, resign, dissimulate (as if ignorant or disowning)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
food (for man or beast), especially bread, or grain (for making it)
to break away (from just authority), i.e. trespass, apostatize, quarrel
properly, a valiant man or warrior; generally, a person simply

22.brief: to tremble inwardly (or palpitate), i.e. (figuratively) be (causative, make) (suddenly) alarmed or agitated; by implication to hasten anxiously
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)

23.brief: to be right (i.e. correct); reciprocal, to argue; causatively, to decide, justify or convict
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
properly, the hind part; generally used as an adverb or conjunction, after (in various senses)
graciousness, i.e. subjective (kindness, favor) or objective (beauty)
properly, to come forth to, i.e. appear or exist; transitively, to attain, i.e. find or acquire; figuratively, to occur, meet or be present
to be smooth (figuratively); by implication (as smooth stones were used for lots) to apportion or separate
the tongue (of man or animals), used literally (as the instrument of licking, eating, or speech), and figuratively (speech, an ingot, a fork of flame, a cove of water)

24.brief: to pluck off; specifically to flay, strip or rob
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application
a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
to decay, i.e. (causatively) ruin (literally or figuratively)

25.brief: roomy, in any (or every) direction, literally or figuratively
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
properly, to grate, i.e. (figuratively) to anger
figuratively, to trust, be confident or sure
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
to be fat; transitively, to fatten (or regard as fat); specifically to anoint; figuratively, to satisfy;  to remove (fat) ashes (of sacrifices)

26.brief: figuratively, to trust, be confident or sure
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly
to walk (in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively)

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
properly, to be smooth, i.e. (by implication) to escape (as if by slipperiness); causatively, to release or rescue; specifically, to bring forth young, emit sparks

27.brief: to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
to veil from sight, i.e. conceal (literally or figuratively)
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)

28.brief: to rise (in various applications, literal, figurative, intensive and causative)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to hide (by covering), literally or figuratively
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
properly, to wander away, i.e. lose oneself; by implication to perish (causative, destroy)
